DATATYPE.Description: A very small integer. The signed range is -128 to 127. The unsigned range is 0 to 255.
A small integer. The signed range is -32768 to 32767. The unsigned range is 0 to 65535.
A medium-size integer. The signed range is -8388608 to 8388607. The unsigned range is 0 to 16777215.
A normal-size integer. The signed range is -2147483648 to 2147483647. The unsigned range is 0 to 4294967295.
A normal-size integer. The signed range is -2147483648 to 2147483647. The unsigned range is 0 to 4294967295.
A large integer. The signed range is -9223372036854775808 to 9223372036854775807. The unsigned range is 0 to 18446744073709551615.
A small (single-precision) floating-point number. Cannot be unsigned. Allowable values are -3.402823466E+38 to -1.175494351E-38, 0, and 1.175494351E-38 to 3.402823466E+38.
A small (single-precision) floating-point number. Cannot be unsigned. Allowable values are -3.402823466E+38 to -1.175494351E-38, 0, and 1.175494351E-38 to 3.402823466E+38.

A normal-size (double-precision) floating-point number. Cannot be unsigned. Allowable values are -1.7976931348623157E+308 to -2.2250738585072014E-308, 0, and 2.2250738585072014E-308 to 1.7976931348623157E+308.
This is a synonym for DOUBLE.
This is a synonym for DOUBLE.
An unpacked floating-point number. Cannot be unsigned. Behaves like a CHAR column.
This is a synonym for DECIMAL.
A date. The supported range is \a1000-01-01\a to \a9999-12-31\a.
A date and time combination. The supported range is \a1000-01-01 00:00:00\a to \a9999-12-31 23:59:59\a.
A timestamp. The range is \a1970-01-01 00:00:00\a to sometime in the year 2037. The length can be 14 (or missing), 12, 10, 8, 6, 4, or 2 representing YYYYMMDDHHMMSS, ... , YYYYMMDD, ... , YY formats.
A time. The range is \a-838:59:59\a to \a838:59:59\a.
A year in 2- or 4-digit format (default is 4-digit).

A fixed-length string (1 to 255 characters) that is always right-padded with spaces to the specified length when stored. values are sorted and compared in case-insensitive fashion according to the default character set unless the BINARY keyword is given.
A variable-length string (1 to 255 characters). Values are sorted and compared in case-sensitive fashion unless the BINARY keyword is given.
This is a synonym for CHAR(1).
This is a synonym for CHAR(1).
A column maximum length of 255 (2^8 - 1) characters. Values are sorted and compared in case-sensitive fashion.
A column maximum length of 65535 (2^16 - 1) characters. Values are sorted and compared in case-sensitive fashion.
A column maximum length of 16777215 (2^24 - 1) characters. Values are sorted and compared in case-sensitive fashion.
A column maximum length of 4294967295 (2^32 - 1) characters. Values are sorted and compared in case-sensitive fashion.
A column maximum length of 255 (2^8 - 1) characters.
A column maximum length of 65535 (2^16 - 1) characters.
A column maximum length of 16777215 (2^24 - 1) characters.
A column maximum length of 4294967295 (2^32 - 1) characters.
An enumeration. A string object that can have only one value, chosen from the list of values.
A set. A string object that can have zero or more values, each of which must be chosen from the list of values.
Geographic Datatype
Geographic Datatype
Geographic Datatype
Geographic Datatype
Geographic Datatype
Geographic Datatype
Geographic Datatype

TABLE.Comments: Any_user entities represent the identifying and authorization information\nfor specific players, admins, and sponsors.
Contact_info entities represent the information necessary to contact\na user by post or telephone.

Player entities represent players. They have user credentials,
and may have associated contact information and payment preference
(for being paid prize money).

Sponsor entities represent game sponsor representatives
eligible to place bids to host the Ball. They have user credentials,
standard contact info, plus an optional (nullable) FAX number, and
a payment method preference (for making payments).
Domain entities represent web sites that (it is hoped) are\neligible to host the Ball. Each is associated with a specific sponsor,\nand is characterized by the base URL of the site.

Image entities represent the domain-specific images associated
with sponsored domains. In addition to a specific domain, each is
associated with a download_obj containing the binary image data. Each
bears a flag indicating whether the image has been approved or rejected,
if any such decision has yet been made.
Admin entities represent Barooka Ball administrators. They\nhave associated user credentials, but nothing else (in this\nversion).
Game entities represent individual Barooka Ball games. They have\na serial number (in the form of their ID), a ball color, and nullable start\nand end dates.
Hosting_block entities aggregate hosting slots, providing for group-wise\nsequencing and provision of slots.

Hosting_slot entities represent specific appearances of the Ball on particular
domains. They are associated with particular hosting blocks indirectly through
bids, and through blocks with specific games. Each has an associated collection
of related brain-teasers, a chain of target objects to find, key details, and a
game-win puzzle. Each is ordered relative to the other slots in its block by a
sequence number, and has associated times when it started and stopped
hosting the Ball, along with a limiting number of minutes that the Ball may remain
in this slot.
Download_obj entities represent binary objects of specified media type.\nThey are generally intended to be provided for download from the server,\nbut can be used internally instead.
Ball_color entities represent the available Ball colors, providing a color\nname and having an associated representative image in the form of a\ndownload_obj.
The plyr_regstrd_game relation establishes which players\nare registered for which games.
The plyr_compltd_slot relation establishes which players have\n\acompleted\a (i.e. found a key or the Ball associated with) which\nhosting slots, and records a timestamp of when they did so.

The plyr_compltd_game relation establishes which players have
completed which games, and provides a global serial number by
which to determine the order in which the players achieved their
game completions.

Target_object entities represent the identifiers of the target
objects in the chain of links associated with a specific hosting
slot. Each one has a sequence number within the chain and a
hex-encoded hash of the target identifier, plus a path (relative
to the host domain) to the location of the target and the ID of
the clue image to provide for this target

A puzzle entity is a generic representation of a puzzle of a puzzle 
a brain-teaser, word puzzle, tile puzzle, jigsaw puzzle, etc. It
provides a reference with which to associate any number of
named \Aattributes\A having string values, and named \Aresources\A
having associated MIME media types, additional string data, and
an associated binary object.
Puzzle_attribute entities associate named attribute strings with\nspecific puzzles.\n

Puzzle_resource entities associate arbitrary binary objects with
specific puzzle entities. They associate a name with MIME media
type information, and a corresponding binary object
The brn_tsr_for_slot relation associates hosting slots with their\nbrain teasers.
The puzzle_for_slot relation associates the appropriate game-win puzzle with\na particular hosting slot.

Represents an auction for slots from a hosting block. Each auction has a specific
start time and end time, a minimum bid, a minimum bid increment, and a count of
individual items for sale. Slots are auctioned anonymously, so that the n highest
bids in each auction win slots (where n is the number of slots in the block).

Represents a bid placed by a sponsor to host the Ball at a specific domain using
a specific domain image. (Domain is implied by image, and sponsor by domain.)
The auto-incrementing id of this table serves to establish a total order of bids
(reception order), even when two or more are received at the same time within
the granularity of the timestamp. The sponsor also specifies the maximum amount
he is willing to pay, for the purpose of automated proxy bidding. The actual
current amount that the sponsor would pay if this bid won (often less than
max_amount) is specified separately, via an effective_bid entity.

An effective_bid entity represents the amount that would be paid by the
bidding sponsor if the associated bid won. This may be updated periodically
by the auction engine in response to automated proxy bidding on behalf of the
bidding sponsor. A bid that has been outbid will not have an associated
effective_bid.
This table supports the E-mail Confirmation component used by Web Registration.
This table supports the TopCoder ID Generator component, version 3.0.
Represents a generic message with category, update timestamp,\nand typed content.
Records game-win events, identifying the winner, win approval\ntimestamp, and payout amount. Presence of a row in this table\nfor a specific game ID signals that that game is over.
Records counts of the number of downloads of the various\nplugins.
